title: SS Empire Banner
text:
Empire Banner was a <a href="cargo%20ship">cargo ship</a> which was built by <a href="Bartram%20%26amp%3B%20Sons">Bartram & Sons Ltd</a>, <a href="Sunderland%2C%20Tyne%20and%20Wear">Sunderland</a> in 1942 for the <a href="Ministry%20of%20War%20Transport">Ministry of War Transport</a> (MoWT). She was <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed by <a href="German%20submarine%20U-77%20%281940%29">"U-77"</a> on 7 February 1943 and sunk later that day by enemy aircraft.
History.
"Empire Banner" was built by Bartram & Sons Ltd, Sunderland as yard number 286. She was launched on 29 June 1942 and completed in September 1942. She was built for the MoWT and was operated under the management of W T Gould & Co Ltd, <a href="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>.
"Empire Banner" was a member of a number of convoys during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>.
Convoy MKS 3X sailed from <a href="Annaba">Bône</a>, <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a> on 3 December 1942 and arrived at <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> on 19 December. "Empire Banner" joined the convoy at <a href="Algiers">Algiers</a> She was fitted with anti-torpedo nets although these were reported as being broken on departure from Algiers.
Convoy KMS 8G which departed the <a href="River%20Clyde">Clyde</a> on 21 January 1943. "Empire Banner" was carrying 3,800 tons of military supplies, including <a href="tank">tank</a>s and other transport. She had departed from <a href="Penarth">Penarth</a> and was destined for Bône. On 7 February 1943, she was torpedoed by <a href="German%20submarine%20U-77%20%281940%29">"U-77"</a> at 02:00 hours. Her position was . "Empire Banner" headed for <a href="Oran">Oran</a> but at 06:00 she was finished off by an enemy aircraft. All 47 crew, 15 DEMS gunners and 10 soldier passengers were rescued by and landed at Algiers.
Official number and code letters.
Official Numbers were a forerunner to <a href="IMO%20ship%20identification%20number">IMO Numbers</a>.
"Empire Banner" had the UK Official Number 169083 and used the <a href="Code%20Letters">Code Letters</a> BCXC.
